content.body: https://twitter.com/assortedhackery/status/1397389032519307266
Is there any particular reason why `function * f () { 0 + yield 1; }` causes `yield` to be interpreted as an identifier?
content.formatted_body: Is there any particular reason why function * f () { 0 + yield 1; } causes yield to be interpreted as an identifier?

content.body: â€¦Oh, right, because `+` has tighter precedence.
content.formatted_body: â€¦Oh, right, because + has tighter precedence.

content.body: Wait, but then how is it possible that `function * f () { x = yield 1; }` is valid? `=` is tighter than `yield`.
content.formatted_body: Wait, but then how is it possible that function * f () { x = yield 1; } is valid? = is tighter than yield.

content.body: Ah, I see, thereâ€™s an AssignmentExpression : YieldExpression production specifically for this caseâ€¦
jschoi: I think "`=` is tighter than `yield`" is false; they're both produced by `AssignmentExpression`
content.formatted_body: jschoi: I think "= is tighter than yield" is false; they're both produced by AssignmentExpression

content.body: that is, I would say they have the same precedence, and bind left-to-right

> <@bakkot:matrix.org> jschoi: I think "`=` is tighter than `yield`" is false; they're both produced by `AssignmentExpression`

Ah, looking at the actual spec, youâ€™re right. I was going off the table in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Operator_Precedence#table â€¦which someone ought to edit and fix, I guess.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @bakkot:matrix.org
jschoi: I think "= is tighter than yield" is false; they're both produced by AssignmentExpression
Ah, looking at the actual spec, youâ€™re right. I was going off the table in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Operator_Precedence#table â€¦which someone ought to edit and fix, I guess.

content.body: that table also lists `??` and `||` as different precedence, which is also wrong
content.formatted_body: that table also lists ?? and || as different precedence, which is also wrong

I'm looking for the bit of static semantics that prevents `while (true) function fn() {}`, I see various early errors for restrictions on labelled statements as the `Statement` of a `WhileStatement` but none for a non-labelled function
content.formatted_body: I'm looking for the bit of static semantics that prevents while (true) function fn() {}, I see various early errors for restrictions on labelled statements as the Statement of a WhileStatement but none for a non-labelled function

content.body: any ideas?
rubber duck strategy,  I think I found it: https://tc39.es/ecma262/#prod-ExpressionStatement
rickbutton: there's no static semantics which prevents it because it's not allowed by the grammar in the first place
content.formatted_body: rickbutton: there's no static semantics which prevents it because it's not allowed by the grammar in the first place

content.body: `function fn() {}` is a Declaration, and the RHS of a `while` is a Statement
content.formatted_body: function fn() {} is a Declaration, and the RHS of a while is a Statement

content.body: there's a special annex-B exception which allows FunctionDeclaration as the RHS of an `if`: https://tc39.es/ecma262/#prod-annexB-IfStatement
content.formatted_body: there's a special annex-B exception which allows FunctionDeclaration as the RHS of an if: https://tc39.es/ecma262/#prod-annexB-IfStatement

content.body: but it's only for `if`, not `while`
content.formatted_body: but it's only for if, not while

content.body: `function fn() {}` could also be a FunctionExpression, which the grammar disallows in a different way, which is I think the way that rickbutton found.
content.formatted_body: function fn() {} could also be a FunctionExpression, which the grammar disallows in a different way, which is I think the way that rickbutton found.

content.formatted_body: ah I see, thanks bakkot

ljharb: bakkot I find the "irc style layout" a lot more readable after hacking the CSS to do this:

.mx_EventTile {
    margin-top: 10px;
}
.mx_IRCLayout .mx_EventTile > .mx_SenderProfile {
    margin-right: 8px;
}

content.body: I use the Stylish browser extension to make it do that
It just adds some more vertical line height between messages, and some more space after the nicks. But without that, it all looks a bit too cramped for my taste at least.

> Maybe that's what I'm not understanding: What's AssertionError?

Justin Ridgewell: it is probably best described in my half-baked (unpresented & unofficial) proposal for it  https://github.com/DerekNonGeneric/proposal-assertion-error
content.formatted_body:
Maybe that's what I'm not understanding: What's AssertionError?

Justin Ridgewell: it is probably best described in my half-baked (unpresented & unofficial) proposal for it https://github.com/DerekNonGeneric/proposal-assertion-error

content.body: Ohhhhhhh
You're talking about things like `assert.equal(actual, expected)`
content.formatted_body: You're talking about things like assert.equal(actual, expected)

content.body: That's very different than AMP's `ExpectedError`
content.formatted_body: That's very different than AMP's ExpectedError

content.body: We're not doing comparisons, "expected" for us is errors that we know will happen in practice and cannot be fixed.
They're not programmer errors, essentially, they're environment errors
We have `ExpectedError` so that we can keep track of them in metrics
content.formatted_body: We have ExpectedError so that we can keep track of them in metrics

content.body: If we see an `ExpectedError` spiking in graphs, we know something in the environment has changed
content.formatted_body: If we see an ExpectedError spiking in graphs, we know something in the environment has changed

content.body: dang, sounds like that could be a separate proposal then ðŸ˜…
looking at a bunch of other languages, almost all of them have an `AssertionError`
content.formatted_body: looking at a bunch of other languages, almost all of them have an AssertionError

content.body: so, i was under the impression that one would be able to use it for run-time feature detection errors, but it seems like that would be an `ExpectedError` in reality
content.formatted_body: so, i was under the impression that one would be able to use it for run-time feature detection errors, but it seems like that would be an ExpectedError in reality

content.body: Yah, that sounds like an `ExpectedError`
content.formatted_body: Yah, that sounds like an ExpectedError

content.body: cool, good to know -- i am going to see if i find time to polish off the rough edges of that proposal and might ping you later on to have a look if you don't mind
